It's hard not to see a brighter future ahead for America, particularly in Texas.

Today, we begin with 115th Congress in Washington. I am as excited today as I was when I entered my first term. We have a historic opportunity in front of us that will help all Americans. This is a responsibility and privilege I do not take lightly.

Rep. Barton announced as Vice-Chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee.   Chairman Greg Walden announced today that Rep. Joe Barton will serve as Vice-Chairman of the Committee on Energy and Commerce for the 115th Congress. Barton has previously held the positions of Chairman and Chairman Emeritus for the committee.   “I am honored to be chosen by Chairman Walden to serve on the committee leadership team as the Vice-Chairman for the full committee,” stated Barton. “This Congress has a historic opportunity to enhance the lives of all Americans and that begins in the Energy and Commerce Committee. I look forward to the work ahead.”   Chairman Walden commented on the appointment, “Joe is a principled conservative with a wealth of knowledge and experience who has become a trusted voice on our committee. As a previous Chairman, he has a solid understanding of the inner workings of our committee and will be a valued asset as we undertake many important policies in the new year. I look forward to having him serve as our Vice-Chairman and know he will do an excellent job.”  The Committee on Energy and Commerce, the oldest standing legislative committee in the U.S. House of Representatives, is vested with the broadest jurisdiction of any congressional authorizing committee. The Energy and Commerce Committee will be one of two committees in the House to work on the repeal and replacement of the Affordable Care Act.
Special thanks to all law enforcement officers today for all they do to keep our communities safe. #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay

Rep. Barton Hosts Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen  Washington: Rep. Joe Barton (R-TX) on Saturday hosted Her Excellency, Tsai Ing-wen, President of the Republic of China (Taiwan) in Houston, Texas. Congressman Barton introduced President Tsai at the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center and the Houston Museum of Fine Arts.  “Last fall, President Tsai graciously invited me to her home. I was grateful to return the favor in Texas. A continued, open dialogue between Taiwan and the United States will help advance both nations,” stated Barton. “I thank President Tsai for visiting Texas and look forward to our continued friendship.”  駐美國台北經濟文化代表處 Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the US蔡英文 Tsai Ing-wenMD Anderson Cancer Center #Taiwan

Texas Republican Rep. Joe L. Barton has attended every inauguration since he was elected in 1984, except for President Barack Obama’s second. But his favorite memory was from President Ronald Reagan’s second inaugural ceremony in 1985, which was moved into the Rotunda due to frigid temperatures.   Barton recalled going to the House chamber after the ceremony, and stopping at the Cloakroom. He said he was the only one there when, to his surprise, actor Jimmy Stewart walked in. The congressman recalled them chatting for a few minutes, and he told Stewart how much he enjoyed the film “Mr. Smith Goes to Washington.”  As further proof that you never know who you’ll run into around inauguration time, Barton remembered going to a party that same year at the Mayflower Hotel. He got out of his cab, and Dean Martin and Frank Sinatra took it next.
My entire staff is up in Washington today for meetings and in preparation for the Presidential Inauguration. We are ready to serve you! #MAGA

Rep. Barton: “It’s About Time” on POTUS’ Executive Actions  Washington: Rep. Joe Barton (R-TX), Vice Chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, released the following statement on President Trump’s executive actions, which removed barriers for the completion of both the Dakota Access Pipeline and the Keystone XL Pipeline.   “It’s about time. After years of delay, President Trump has decidedly put American interests ahead of the harmful climate agenda of the last eight years. The approval of Keystone XL and Dakota Access will create jobs and continue to spur our economy,” stated Barton. “I commend President Trump for his early action and commitment to the energy sector.”

Washington: Today, Rep. Joe Barton (R-Ennis) voted for H.R. 7, the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion and Abortion Insurance Full Disclosure Act of 2017. This bill prohibits federal funds from being used for abortions by making the Hyde Amendment, and all other federally funded abortion prohibitions, permanent. Congress has passed the Hyde Amendment each year since 1976.   “All life is precious and should be respected, especially that of the unborn. H.R. 7 ensures that taxpayer dollars are not used for abortions in any way, shape, or form. As a lawmaker, I believe I have a constitutional and moral obligation to protect those who do not have the power to protect themselves."

Washington: Today, Energy and Commerce Committee Vice-Chairman Joe Barton (R-TX) issued the following statement after the U.S. Senate confirmed Rick Perry as Secretary of the Department of Energy.  “In 1981, I began my career in public service as a White House Fellow at the Department of Energy (DOE). Back then, DOE helped Americans gain affordable and reliable energy, oversaw our nuclear program in the name of national security, and encouraged science and innovation in ways the private sector was incapable. More recently, this Department, like so many others, has fallen victim to excessive bureaucracy and bloated government spending accounts that detract from its original mission.   “Fortunately, we now have a man who possesses a very strong energy background and has a track record of proven executive leadership. I have known Governor Perry since we were classmates at Texas A&M. We have since worked hand in hand on countless projects, and I am sure our relationship will grow even stronger over the coming months and years as we work to return the Department of Energy to its core mission and reduce waste.  “Welcome to Washington, Mr. Secretary. I could not be more proud to have a friend, Texan, and Aggie at the helm of the Department of Energy.”
Today, I helped with with the ribbon cutting of the Center Street Bridge in Arlington. One of many exciting infrastructure projects going on in Arlington.

Live on C-SPAN right now is the House Committee on Energy and Commerce markup for the repeal and replace of Obamacare. As Vice-Chairman of the committee, I am currently filling in for Chairman Walden.
Here's a live look at the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. We are entering the 20th hour of the markup and are no less determined to repeal and replace Obamacare.

Washington: Rep Joe Barton (R-TX) released the following statement following the passage of legislation to repeal and replace Obamacare at the House Energy and Commerce Committee:  "For eight long years, the American people have seen the disastrous consequences of Obamacare. Premiums and deductibles have gone up, insurance choices have gone down, and American families have suffered. Across the 6th District, I have heard from those that simply could not afford health insurance and small business owners that were forced to close their doors due to overbearing health insurance costs. That’s why we worked through the night at the Energy and Commerce Committee – to begin to rebuild our broken health system. "While a huge step forward, this is not a perfect bill. House Republicans made a commitment to repeal Obamacare and this bill, in its current form, does not go far enough. "I along with Reps. Blackburn (R-TN) and Hudson (R-NC) offered two substantive amendments. Our amendments would move up the freeze date for new enrollment in the Medicaid expansion at the enhanced match under Obamacare to January 1, 2018. Additionally, the end date for enrollees to phase out of the expanded program would be established as January 1, 2023. States would still receive Medicaid benefits from the federal government at the rates established before Obamacare. These amendments would result in billions of dollars of savings due to the shortened timetable for ending Obamacare Medicaid expansion funding. They will remain under consideration as we continue to work through the legislative process. "Our work is far from done, but it has begun. A 27 hour markup will not deter our mission."

"What's next: Rep. Joe Barton withdrew one important amendment he had expected to offer: ending Obamacare's Medicaid expansion at the end of this year rather than in 2020. That was a concession to conservatives, and has already been endorsed by groups like the Republican Study Committee. Barton said the White House is "looking at it" and that he has gotten a "considerable amount of positive feedback" in private conversations. So look for it to return later in the process."

The postponement of the vote does not mean the issue is dead in this Congress. It does mean the bill in its current form needs to be improved. I intend to be a part of that improvement.   The bill that was withdrawn in the House today was not a perfect bill, and it did not totally repeal or totally replace the ACA. It did, however, make a good start in that direction. It repealed the individual and employer mandates. It repealed almost all of the ACA taxes. It defunded Planned Parenthood. It put in place a mechanism to slow the rate of growth in Medicaid spending. The bill also repealed the federal mandate on essential health benefits.   Health care is a very important issue for all of us. There are no easy fixes. It is important that we go back to the negotiating table and improve the bill – next time it will pass.

Watch Live: I am with President Trump at the EPA to announce an executive order directing a review of the Clean Power Plan. This will help bring back jobs in the energy sector, and create economic growth in Texas and around the nation.

Washington: Rep. Joe Barton (R-TX) joins President Trump at the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for the signing of an executive order to review and rewrite the Clean Power Plan.    “In Texas, we know better than most that energy creates opportunity. By the same token, over-regulation kills jobs and hinders economic growth. Today, President Trump fulfilled a promise to undo the politically motivated, global warming agenda of the Obama Presidency. This executive order will help free Texas and our other states from emissions regulation that would close power plants and increase families’ energy bills. Along with legislation from Congress, this order will allow our energy sector to thrive while also promoting safe air and water for all Americans.”

Rep. Barton to Host April Town Hall Meetings  Washington: Rep Joe Barton is pleased to announce a second series of town hall meetings for 2017. Each year, Rep. Barton hosts several hour-long meetings that give him an opportunity to meet with residents of the Sixth Congressional District of Texas and hear about the issues that are important to them.  Rep. Barton will begin the meetings with an update on his priorities and activities in Washington. He will then open the floor to a question and answer session. All residents of the Sixth District are invited to attend one of the meetings. These three announced town hall meetings represent substantial population centers within each of the three counties of the Sixth Congressional District.  Corsicana Town Hall Meeting  April 11, 2017  1:30 p.m.  Corsicana Government Center, City Council Chambers  200 North 12th Street  Corsicana, TX 75110  Mansfield Town Hall Meeting  April 13, 2017  12:00 p.m.  Mansfield City Hall, Council Chambers  1200 East Broad Street   Mansfield, TX 76063  Waxahachie Town Hall Meeting  April 20, 2017  6:00 p.m.  Waxahachie City Hall, Council Chambers  401 South Rogers Street  Waxahachie, TX 75165

WAXAHACHIE — As Lillian and Sharon patiently waited for a hot lunch to make its way into their homes, Congressman Joe Barton was slipping on a “Let’s do lunch” t-shirt and headed out with two coolers in hand for an afternoon of volunteering.  The Meals on Wheels program, especially the Meals on Wheels of Johnson and Ellis Counties, is one Barton said he holds in high regard. Barton has served the constituents of the 6th Congressional District of Texas in the United States House of Representatives for the last 32 years.  “In my hometown of Ennis, I have been a longtime advocate for Meals on Wheels,” Barton said. “They provide an invaluable service in the delivery of meals, social contact, and safety checks to our most vulnerable citizens.”  Meals on Wheels America Meals on Wheels of Johnson & Ellis Counties #DeliverAct

Yesterday I had the honor and pleasure of touring Joe Pool Lake in the 6th District of Texas. Joe Pool Lake serves the City of Midlothian as a water reservoir for their public water supply. In addition, Joe Pool Lake has been a favorite destination of residents of the Dallas – Fort Worth Metroplex for over 25 years ago. I offer a special thank you to Mr. Kevin Ward for guiding me through the property and informing me of current topics of discussion such as current water storage levels. As the 115th Congress works to progress legislation for comprehensive transportation and infrastructure improvements, it is very important to me to re-familiarize myself with the potential needs in our community.   Joe Pool Lake Trinity River Authority

The first 100 days of a presidency is an artificial measurement of our commander in chief’s capabilities. Despite liberal media claims that President Trump has underachieved in his first 100 days, his record offers conflicting evidence. President Trump, along with Congress, has signed 25 executive orders, enacted 28 pieces of legislation, and removed numerous burdensome regulations from the previous administration. Furthermore, the President has led the nomination and appointment of Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch, driven powerful national security reinforcement policies and salvaged our nation’s place as a leader in trade and economic development. I am proud of our President’s successes and look forward working with him and my colleagues for a successful next 1360 days.

One of our President’s pronounced priorities throughout his campaign and presidency has been sustaining and advancing  National Security. The safety of Americans must remain one of our highest concerns as we face a world of chaos. President Trump has confronted those who seek to do us harm through executive orders to restrict travel from specific terrorist nations, airstrikes on the Syrian Airfield in retaliation to the Syrian Government’s use of chemical weapons, and strategic sanctions. I am honored to serve with a President who values the safety and advancement of our great nation.

On this historic day, I spoke on the House Floor in favor of the repeal and replace of Obamacare. "I choose less government mandates and more personal freedom... Let's restore markets and freedom to healthcare in America." #AHCA

Washington: Rep. Joe Barton (R-TX) released the following statement on House passage of the American Health Care Act to repeal and replace Obamacare.   “I made a promise to Texans that I would work tirelessly to repeal and replace Obamacare. Today, marked a substantial step forward when the House passed of the American Health Care Act (AHCA). The AHCA will expand choices, lower premiums and deductibles, and help reduce the national deficit.   “Obamacare has failed to provide better coverage at lower costs through government mandates. Americans are capable and, when given the necessary facts and options, they will find the best fit for themselves and their families. There is still work to be done and I will work with my colleagues in the Senate to get this bill to the President’s desk.”   Rep. Barton serves as Vice-Chair of the Energy and Commerce Committee, one of three committees of jurisdiction for this legislation.
Today, I met with Sheriff Bill Waybourn and many other from the Tarrant County Sheriff's Office. Always great to hear about some of the innovative law enforcement work in North Texas.

How the tables have turned....  "I think [OPEC] are now acutely aware that they don't have the kind of influence they used to have 10 years ago, and that shale is now the swing producer in the market," Tom Pugh, commodities economist at Capital Economics, said last week.
This week is National Police Week, a week to pay tribute to fallen officers and honor their service. Thank you to all of our law enforcement officers in Texas and around the nation.

ENNIS, TX – Rep. Joe Barton (R-Ennis) announced that the Ennis Fire Department has been awarded a $147,510 grant by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security.  “This grant will help the Ennis Fire Department obtain the tools and training it needs to better provide for the safety and security of both firefighters and the residents they are charged with protecting,” Barton said. “I’m pleased to announce this well-deserved grant, and want to thank Chief Aycock along with each and every member of the Ennis Fire Department for their service to the community.”  The grant has specifically been designated for “Operations and Firefighter Safety,” and will assist the Ennis Fire Department in obtaining new hoses, nozzles, and valves for fire engines. The grant is provided through the Assistance to Firefighters Grant Program (AFG).

WASHINGTON - Rep. Joe Barton (R-TX) was recognized with the 2017 United States Energy Award by the United States Energy Association. Congressman Barton received the award in recognition of his outstanding efforts to advance global energy initiatives and his support of the United States energy industry.   “I am honored to receive this award, and truly humbled to see my name listed among this award's past recipients,” Barton said. “Throughout my career I have worked to strengthen the energy sector and provide Americans with affordable and reliable sources of energy. Today we are blessed to lead the world in energy production – a position we will not soon lose.”  The U.S. Energy Award has been presented annually since 1989. Barton is the first member of the House of Representatives to receive the award. The award was given last year to current Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson.

Who's looking forward to the 2017 Congressional Baseball Game for Charity? The game is on June 15th, so we only have a few more early morning practices left. Our team meets every morning that Congress is in session at 6:30 am for an hour practice before we head up to Capitol Hill.

"On June 6, 1944, more than 160,000 Allied troops landed along a 50-mile stretch of heavily-fortified French coastline, to fight Nazi Germany on the beaches of Normandy, France. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower called the operation a crusade in which, “we will accept nothing less than full victory.” More than 5,000 Ships and 13,000 aircraft supported the D-Day invasion, and by day’s end, the Allies gained a foot-hold in Continental Europe. The cost in lives on D-Day was high. More than 9,000 Allied Soldiers were killed or wounded, but their sacrifice allowed more than 100,000 Soldiers to begin the slow, hard slog across Europe, to defeat Adolf Hitler’s crack troops." #DDayPlus73

What are your thoughts on self-driving cars? I am working with my colleagues at the House Committee on Energy and Commerce on legislation to allow for expanded testing across the United States. Our goal is to make transportation safer and more efficient for all Americans.

Oil exports continue to increase and OPEC's global influence continues to decrease. Lifting the ban on crude oil exports has been a win for consumers, jobs, and producers. I first introduced the bill to end the ban on exports in 2014, then again in 2015. We finally made it happen in December of 2015 and look where we are now.   When we lifted the ban in December 2015, here's what I said:   “This represents the most substantial energy policy enacted in a generation,” stated Barton. “Of the remaining scarcity energy policies from the 1970s, lifting the ban on exports was the last vestige of unnecessary government overreach from the time. We have given all Americans a big Christmas present- one that will provide tens of thousands of jobs, bolster our economy, and keep the energy revolution in America alive and well.”  “Lifting the ban will have an immediate impact on all Texans. As rig counts have been down, we must keep the energy boom alive. At a time of global unrest, energy security is one of the surest ways to maintain and grow our influence in volatile areas around the world. Today, the American people won and with US crude on the world market, the world is a better place.”

Washington: Rep. Joe Barton (R-Ennis) released the following statement after the House passed H.R. 10, the Financial CHOICE Act:  “For years, the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act has hurt local and community banks and limited Americans’ access to credit.  “The Financial CHOICE Act will put Americans back in the driver seat and promote economic growth across the country – not just on Wall Street. This bill supports local and community banks that serve as a vital link between Americans and their access to credit. No American business should be ‘too big to fail’ and receive a handout from American tax payers. I commend my friend and colleague, Chairman Hensarling, on working to get this measure passed.”

As the manager of the Republican Congressional Baseball team, I am deeply saddened by this morning’s events. Members, staff, and support personnel arrived around 6:30 a.m. to Simpson Field for our usual morning practice. Shortly after 7 a.m., shots were fired from a high caliber firearm. The suspect was shooting at members and staff on the field. Officers of the Capitol Police returned fire and ran towards the shooter, risking their lives while saving others. The incident lasted for approximately 10 minutes. Several people were injured, including Majority Whip Steve Scalise. The Alexandria Police along with the Capitol Police secured a cease-fire, capturing the suspect.   My thoughts and prayers are with Rep. Scalise and his family, along with the others injured in this attack. My gratitude goes to the brave men and women who risked their lives to bring the shooter down.   This morning was scheduled as the final practice for the Republican team for the year. The Congressional Baseball Game for Charity is scheduled for 7:05 p.m., tomorrow night, June 15. A final decision has not been made regarding the scheduled game.

Today, at the House Committee on Energy and Commerce we will take a major step forward in solving our nation's nuclear waste issue. Texans have for years paid the federal government for a long term waste solution that has never materialized. Our work today will help get this program back on track!  You can watch the committee live with the link below.

Finding a long-term solution for our nuclear waste has  long been a priority of mine. Today, we re-started progress on the long-stalled Yucca Mountain. I commend my colleagues on both sides of the aisle for coming together and working in a bipartisan way to solve a national priority.

Rep. Barton (R-Ennis) released the following statement following the Energy and Commerce Committee’s approval of H.R. 3053, the Nuclear Waste Policy Amendments Act of 2017.  “Today, we jump-started progress on the long-stalled Yucca Mountain Nuclear Repository. I commend my colleagues on both sides of the aisle for coming together and working in a bipartisan way to solve a national priority.  “Once this bill is signed into law, Yucca Mountain can move forward as our national nuclear waste storage depository. The bill will also allow for a single temporary interim storage facility until Yucca is complete. High-level nuclear waste needs a safe, secure home and should no longer be stranded around the nation. Thirty years ago, the federal government committed to a permanent repository for nuclear waste - it is time we make good on that promise.”   Rep. Barton has worked tirelessly for over two decades to move the ball forward on safe and secure high-level waste storage, both long-term and interim. Nuclear waste is at present stored on-site at nuclear power generators that are often near communities, which raises both security and safety concerns.

Washington, D.C.: Today, Reps. Barton (R-TX) and Doyle (D-PA) introduced the Wounded Officers Recovery Act of 2017 (H.R. 3298) on behalf of over one hundred Members of Congress - including each player in this year’s Congressional Baseball Game. The bipartisan, bicameral bill will amend the United States Capitol Police Memorial Fund to expand eligibility to include any United States Capitol Police employee that has been injured in the line of duty. The fund at present only allows funds donated to be distributed to families of officers killed in the line of duty. A companion bill will be introduced by the Senate baseball players later this week.   “Sometimes, even simple and caring gestures require an act of Congress. Following the tragic shooting on June 14th, the Congressional Baseball game achieved record setting crowds and donations for local charities. This year we will be donating a portion of the funds raised to help those injured at the baseball practice,” said Barton. “Officers Bailey and Griner saved my life along with those of my sons and of everyone out at that field. This bill allows the United States Capitol Police Memorial Fund to distribute funds to any of their employees who are seriously injured in the line of duty. Officers Bailey and Griner have received a great deal of care and will require more - the members of the baseball teams wish to make sure they have the necessary resources for recovery.”    “Over the years, a number of Capitol Police Officers have been killed or injured in the line of duty,” Congressman Doyle observed. “Every member of the House and Senate understand the risks that are willingly taken by these officers every day to keep us, our staffs, and the Capitol’s many visitors safe. The Capitol Police Memorial Fund was originally established with a specific limited purpose – namely, to make it easier for individuals to provide financial support for the families of two Capitol Police Officers killed in the line of duty in 1998. In light of the attack on the Congressional Republicans’ baseball practice last month, in which two Capitol Police Officers were wounded while bravely working to stop the gunman, we believe that the law should be amended to allow the Fund to provide similar support to US Capitol Police Officers seriously injured in the line of duty.”
NA

WASHINGTON, D.C.: Today, Reps. Joe Barton (R-TX) and Kathy Castor (D-FL) introduced the Advancing Care for Exceptional Kids Act of 2017 (ACE Kids Act), H.R. 3325. The ACE Kids Act will help improve the coordination of and access to high quality care to ensure optimal outcomes for children with complex medical conditions on Medicaid, while assisting to contain costs. Other original cosponsors in the House include; Reps. Gene Green, Anna Eshoo, Dave Reichert, and Jaime Herrera Beutler. A similar bill, S. 428, was introduced in the Senate in February  Most children with complex medical conditions receive care from multiple pediatric providers at multiple locations whom they access through Medicaid. The state-by-state variability of Medicaid programs and lack of a coordinated care plan creates a care system that is often fragmented and unnecessarily burdensome for these children and families who frequently cross state lines to access specialized care.  “This bill is about giving our nations sickest children better care. It cuts through the bureaucratic red tape and tries to save the taxpayers some money. This innovative approach Congresswoman Castor and I have worked to draft has received buy in from children’s hospitals, primary and specialty care providers, state Medicaid directors, and family advocates,” said Rep. Barton. “We are confident this bill is ready to move through Congress and land on the President’s desk.”  “The goal of the bipartisan ACE Kids Act is simple: put children with complex medical conditions and their families first,” U.S. Rep. Castor said. “A medical home that coordinates care also saves precious time and money for families. I am proud of St. Joseph's Children's Hospital Chronic-Complex Clinic in Tampa, Fla., for leading the nation with its medical home model, and I look forward to working with my colleague, U.S. Rep. Barton, to help pass this legislation.”     Background on the ACE Kids Act:  Medicaid covers roughly 30 million children; approximately 6 percent of these children have complex medical conditions yet account for 40 percent of Medicaid spending on children.  The ACE Kids Act of 2017 is designed to improve care for medically complex children in Medicaid, while also reducing spending. Published studies show cost savings and improved quality of care for this population when enrolled in an integrated and coordinated care program.  In the 114th Congress, the ACE Kids Act was supported by 43 cosponsors in the Senate and 228 cosponsors in the House. In the 115th Congress, S. 428 has 17 bipartisan cosponsors at present.   The ACE Kids Act is optional for states, children and families, and health care providers.

Check out this article I wrote on the important work we are doing for children with complex medical conditions. U.S. Rep. Kathy Castor have worked for over three years on this bill and have received buy in from children’s hospitals, primary and specialty care providers, state Medicaid directors, and family advocates.

WASHINGTON: Rep. Joe Barton released the following statement after voting against the Senate Amendment to House Amendment to Senate Amendment to H.R. 601: Hurricane Supplemental, Debt Limit, Continuing Appropriations, and Flood Insurance Package.  "Earlier this week, I voted for an emergency relief package for victims of Hurricane Harvey. That package went to the Senate, where it was attached to a much larger public debt ceiling extension.  “Today, when the hurricane relief-debt ceiling increase bill came back from the Senate, I voted no. I am not against voting for relief programs to help hurricane victims, but I am against raising the public debt ceiling without a plan to reduce deficits in the short term, and eliminate them in the long term. The money we vote to spend today will have to be paid back by our children and grandchildren. We have yet again missed an opportunity for substantial reforms and reduced spending.  “The debt ceiling extension runs until the middle of December. Between now and then, I am going to work to craft a package of budget reforms with the goal of balancing the federal budget, so we do not continue to raise the public debt ceiling.”

Rep. Joe Barton (R-Texas) on Tuesday floated the possibility that credit-monitoring firms like Equifax pay consumers if their accounts are hacked, noting continual security breaches could mean hearings each year.  “We could have this hearing every year from now on if we don’t do something to change the current system,” Barton said to former Equifax CEO Richard Smith during his testimony in front of the House Commerce subcommittee on consumer protection.   “I would hope that you’d go back to your peers and work with the committee chairman and the subcommittee chairman, ranking member, and let’s figure out something to do that actually gives an incentive to the industry to protect ourselves,” the Texas Republican added.  Barton, a founder of the bipartisan Congressional Privacy Caucus, said the only solution he sees is to fine Equifax for each account that is breached.

WASHINGTON: Rep. Joe Barton (R-Ennis) released the following statement Tuesday after voting for H.R. 36, the “Pain Capable Unborn Child Protection Act.” The legislation passed the House by a bipartisan vote of  237-189.  “Growing scientific evidence shows that unborn children can feel pain at 20 weeks of fetal age and beyond. These are babies just like the ones we see in Neonatal Intensive Care Units in hospitals in our area struggling for life, needing love.  “This bill will ban abortions in the United States after the 20 week threshold. The only exceptions are when the life of the mother is in danger or in cases of rape and incest. This bill won’t end all abortion, but it will prevent future suffering and death.  “All life is precious and should be respected and I back that up with my vote. I have a constitutional and moral obligation to protect those who do not have the power to protect themselves. I will continue to fight in Congress for the unborn."

Washington, DC – The co-chairs of the Congressional Privacy Caucus, Rep. Joe Barton (R-TX) and Rep. Diana DeGette (D-CO), today sent a letter to Equifax Interim CEO Paulino do Rego Barros Jr. requesting information on any additional programs that his company plans to implement to assist the 145 million people whose data was compromised in the breach that was disclosed last month.  “It is important to understand Equifax’s decision-making process regarding consumer remedies given the historic size of the breach,” the letter said, “… and the potential decades-long effects of stolen personal information on the privacy and financial security of breach victims.”   Noting that there is no national standard for the types of remedies that should be offered to people whose data has been compromised, the two legislators recommended that Equifax consider the steps taken by the Office of Personnel Management after federal employees’ data was compromised in 2015, such as credit and financial monitoring, dark web monitoring, public records monitoring and stolen funds reimbursement.

Washington, DC - Rep. Joe Barton (R-Ennis) joined a bipartisan group of his colleagues in a letter to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) Acting Director Thomas Brandon. The group of lawmakers request that the ATF reevaluate bump stocks and similar mechanisms to ensure full compliance with federal law.  “Evidence suggests the perpetrator of the horrific attacks in Las Vegas on October 2nd may have used a commercially obtainable bump stock to modify the rate at which shots can be fired. While we cannot legislate away hate and anger that is the root of evil acts like the one in Las Vegas, we can and should evaluate means to deter and slow the damage," stated Barton. "I have and always will be a strong proponent of the Second Amendment. Mentally competent, law-abiding citizens must have the right to own a firearm. It is my hope through these reviews and other commonsense proposals we can collectively find a way forward.”

Yesterday, I voted for the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act. It passed the House 231-198. This legislation allowed gun owners that have a concealed carry permit in their home state the ability  to carry their gun with them when they travel to other states. To me, this is just common-sense. It is a big victory for the 2nd Amendment and law abiding citizens.  The bill now goes to the Senate. In the past, 7 Democratic Senators have voted for similar legislation, so if one more Democratic Senator can be convinced to vote for the bill, cloture can be invoked and the bill can be voted on and sent to President Trump. 60 votes are needed for cloture.
